title: です (desu)
explanation: です is the polite form of the copula, used to state that something is something else. It comes at the end of a sentence and makes the sentence polite.

exampleSentences.reading: がくせいです。
これはほんです。

title: じゃないです / ではありません
meaning: Negative copula - is not, am not, are not
structure: [Noun] じゃないです / ではありません
explanation: The negative form of です. じゃないです is more casual, while ではありません is more formal. Both mean 'is not'.

exampleSentences.reading: がくせいじゃないです。

exampleSentences.japanese: 日本人ではありません。
exampleSentences.reading: にほんじんではありません。

title: は (wa) - Topic marker
meaning: Marks the topic of the sentence
explanation: は marks what the sentence is about (the topic). It tells the listener what you are going to talk about, then you add information about that topic.

exampleSentences.reading: わたしはがくせいです。
とうきょうはおおきいです。

title: が (ga) - Subject marker
meaning: Marks the subject of the sentence
explanation: が marks the subject, especially when introducing new information, expressing preferences, or with certain verbs like ある, いる, 分かる, and 好き.

exampleSentences.reading: ねこがいます。
にほんごがすきです。

title: を (wo) - Object marker
meaning: Marks the direct object of a verb
explanation: を marks the direct object that receives the action of the verb. It tells you what is being acted upon.

exampleSentences.reading: ほんをよみます。
みずをのみます。

title: に (ni) - Location/Time/Direction
meaning: Indicates location of existence, time, or direction of movement
explanation: に has multiple uses: it marks the time when something happens, the location where something exists (with いる/ある), and the destination of movement.

exampleSentences.reading: しちじにおきます。
がっこうにいきます。

title: で (de) - Location of action / Means
meaning: Indicates where an action takes place or the means by which something is done
explanation: で marks the location where an action takes place (unlike に which marks where something exists) and the means or tool used to do something.

exampleSentences.reading: がっこうでべんきょうします。
でんしゃでいきます。

title: へ (e) - Direction
explanation: へ (pronounced え when used as a particle) indicates the direction of movement. It is similar to に but emphasizes the direction rather than the destination itself.

exampleSentences.reading: にほんへいきます。

title: と (to) - And / With
explanation: と connects two or more nouns meaning 'and', or indicates doing something with someone.

exampleSentences.japanese: パンと牛乳を買います。
exampleSentences.reading: パンとぎゅうにゅうをかいます。
ともだちといきます。

title: も (mo) - Also / Too
explanation: も replaces は, が, or を to indicate that something is also true, or that it applies equally to another item.

exampleSentences.reading: わたしもがくせいです。

title: の (no) - Possessive / Modifier
meaning: Shows possession or modifies a noun
explanation: の connects two nouns, showing that Noun A possesses, describes, or is related to Noun B. It functions like 'of' or 's in English.

exampleSentences.reading: わたしのほんです。
にほんごのせんせいです。

title: か (ka) - Question marker
meaning: Turns a statement into a question
explanation: か is added at the end of a sentence to turn it into a question. In polite speech, the intonation rises naturally with か.

exampleSentences.reading: がくせいですか。
なにをたべますか。

title: ます form - Polite verb form
explanation: The ます form is the polite way to express verbs in the present or future tense. It is the standard form used in everyday polite conversation.

exampleSentences.reading: まいにち、ほんをよみます。
あした、とうきょうにいきます。
exampleSentences.english: I will go to Tokyo tomorrow.

title: ました - Polite past tense
explanation: ました is the polite past tense form. It expresses that an action was completed in the past.

exampleSentences.reading: きのう、えいがをみました。

title: ません - Polite negative
explanation: ません is the polite negative form. It expresses that an action does not or will not happen.

exampleSentences.reading: にくをたべません。

title: ませんでした - Polite negative past
explanation: ませんでした is the polite past negative form. It expresses that an action did not happen in the past.

exampleSentences.japanese: 昨日は勉強しませんでした。
exampleSentences.reading: きのうはべんきょうしませんでした。

title: て form (te-form)
meaning: Connective verb form used for requests, linking actions, and more
explanation: The te-form is one of the most versatile verb forms. It connects actions in sequence, makes requests (てください), and forms progressive tense (ている). Formation varies by verb group.

exampleSentences.reading: たべてください。
ほんをよんで、ねました。
exampleSentences.english: I read a book, then went to sleep.

title: ている (te-iru) - Progressive / State
meaning: Indicates an ongoing action or resulting state
explanation: ている expresses an action currently in progress (like English '-ing') or a state resulting from a completed action.

exampleSentences.reading: いま、たべています。
とうきょうにすんでいます。

title: てください (te kudasai) - Please do
meaning: Polite request form - please do something
explanation: てください is used to make polite requests, asking someone to do something.

exampleSentences.japanese: ここに名前を書いてください。
exampleSentences.reading: ここになまえをかいてください。

title: ないでください - Please don't
meaning: Polite negative request - please don't do something
explanation: ないでください is used to politely ask someone not to do something.

exampleSentences.japanese: 写真を撮らないでください。
exampleSentences.reading: しゃしんをとらないでください。

title: ない form - Negative
explanation: The ない form is the plain negative form of verbs. For ichidan verbs, replace る with ない. For godan verbs, change the final syllable to the あ-row and add ない. する becomes しない, くる becomes こない.

exampleSentences.reading: あさごはんをたべない。

title: たい (tai) - Want to
meaning: Expresses the speaker's desire to do something
explanation: たい is attached to the verb stem to express the speaker's desire to do something. It conjugates like an い-adjective. It is only used for the speaker's own desires or in questions.

exampleSentences.reading: にほんにいきたいです。
exampleSentences.english: I want to go to Japan.

exampleSentences.reading: なにをたべたいですか。
exampleSentences.english: What do you want to eat?

title: から / まで - From / Until
meaning: Indicates starting point (from) and ending point (until/to)
explanation: から marks the starting point in time or space, while まで marks the endpoint. They can be used together or separately.

exampleSentences.japanese: 九時から五時まで働きます。
exampleSentences.reading: くじからごじまではたらきます。

exampleSentences.japanese: 東京から大阪まで新幹線で行きます。
exampleSentences.reading: とうきょうからおおさかまでしんかんせんでいきます。
exampleSentences.english: I go from Tokyo to Osaka by bullet train.

title: けど / が - But
explanation: けど (casual) and が (more formal) connect two sentences with a contrasting or qualifying relationship. が is also used to soften statements or introduce topics.

exampleSentences.japanese: 高いですけど、おいしいです。
exampleSentences.reading: たかいですけど、おいしいです。

title: ましょう (mashou) - Let's
explanation: ましょう is used to suggest doing something together, equivalent to 'let's' or 'shall we' in English.

exampleSentences.reading: いっしょにたべましょう。
いきましょうか。

title: がある / がいる - Existence
meaning: Expresses the existence of inanimate (ある) or animate (いる) things
structure: [Place] に [Thing] が ある/いる
explanation: ある is used for inanimate objects and いる is used for living things (people, animals). They express that something exists at a location.

exampleSentences.japanese: 机の上に本があります。
exampleSentences.reading: つくえのうえにほんがあります。
exampleSentences.english: There is a book on the desk.

exampleSentences.reading: にわにねこがいます。
exampleSentences.english: There is a cat in the garden.

title: い-adjective conjugation
structure: [い-adj] → Past: ~かった / Negative: ~くない / Past neg: ~くなかった
explanation: い-adjectives conjugate by removing い and adding the appropriate ending. Past: かった, Negative: くない, Past negative: くなかった.

exampleSentences.reading: きのうはあつかったです。

exampleSentences.japanese: この本はおもしろくないです。
exampleSentences.reading: このほんはおもしろくないです。

title: な-adjective conjugation
structure: [な-adj] + だ/です → Past: だった / Negative: じゃない / Modifying: な + Noun
explanation: な-adjectives conjugate with the copula. They use な when modifying nouns directly. Negative: じゃない/ではない, Past: だった/でした.

exampleSentences.reading: このまちはしずかです。
きれいなはなです。

title: より / 一番 - Comparisons
structure: A は B より [Adjective] / A が 一番 [Adjective]
explanation: より is used to compare two things (A is more ~ than B). 一番 means 'the most' and is used for superlatives.

exampleSentences.japanese: 東京は大阪より大きいです。
exampleSentences.reading: とうきょうはおおさかよりおおきいです。

exampleSentences.japanese: 日本語が一番好きです。
exampleSentences.reading: にほんごがいちばんすきです。

title: つもり - Intention
meaning: Expresses an intention or plan to do something
explanation: つもり expresses the speaker's intention or plan to do something. It is used with the dictionary form of verbs.

exampleSentences.japanese: 来年、日本に行くつもりです。
exampleSentences.reading: らいねん、にほんにいくつもりです。
exampleSentences.english: I intend to go to Japan next year.

title: と思う (to omou) - I think
meaning: Expresses the speaker's thoughts or opinions
explanation: と思います is used to express the speaker's thoughts, opinions, or beliefs. The clause before と uses the plain form.

exampleSentences.japanese: 明日は雨だと思います。
exampleSentences.reading: あしたはあめだとおもいます。
exampleSentences.english: I think it will rain tomorrow.

exampleSentences.japanese: この本はおもしろいと思います。
exampleSentences.reading: このほんはおもしろいとおもいます。
exampleSentences.english: I think this book is interesting.

title: ことがある - Have experienced
explanation: ことがある is used to express that someone has had the experience of doing something at least once in their life.

exampleSentences.japanese: 日本に行ったことがあります。
exampleSentences.reading: にほんにいったことがあります。

title: 前に / 後に - Before / After
meaning: Indicates before or after an action
structure: [Verb dictionary form] 前に / [Verb た-form] 後に
explanation: 前に means 'before doing' and uses the dictionary form. 後に means 'after doing' and uses the た-form.

exampleSentences.japanese: 食べる前に、手を洗います。
exampleSentences.reading: たべるまえに、てをあらいます。
exampleSentences.english: I wash my hands before eating.

exampleSentences.japanese: 食べた後に、歯を磨きます。
exampleSentences.reading: たべたあとに、はをみがきます。
exampleSentences.english: I brush my teeth after eating.

title: あげる / もらう / くれる - Giving and receiving
structure: [Person] に [Object] を あげる/もらう/くれる
explanation: あげる means to give (from speaker outward). もらう means to receive. くれる means someone gives to the speaker or speaker's in-group.

exampleSentences.japanese: 友達にプレゼントをあげました。
exampleSentences.reading: ともだちにプレゼントをあげました。
exampleSentences.english: I gave a present to my friend.

exampleSentences.japanese: 先生に本をもらいました。
exampleSentences.reading: せんせいにほんをもらいました。
exampleSentences.english: I received a book from my teacher.

title: 方 (かた) - How to
explanation: 方 attached to the verb stem means 'the way of doing' or 'how to do'. It turns a verb into a noun meaning the method.

exampleSentences.japanese: この漢字の読み方を教えてください。
exampleSentences.reading: このかんじのよみかたをおしえてください。
exampleSentences.english: Please teach me how to read this kanji.

exampleSentences.japanese: 使い方が分かりません。
exampleSentences.reading: つかいかたがわかりません。
exampleSentences.english: I don't know how to use it.

title: なる - To become
structure: [い-adj stem] く なる / [な-adj / Noun] に なる
explanation: なる means 'to become'. With い-adjectives, remove い and add くなる. With な-adjectives and nouns, add になる.

exampleSentences.japanese: 日本語が上手になりました。
exampleSentences.reading: にほんごがじょうずになりました。
さむくなりました。

title: た form - Plain past
explanation: The た form expresses past tense in plain/casual speech. Its formation follows the same rules as the て form, but ends in た/だ instead of て/で.

exampleSentences.reading: きのう、ほんをよんだ。
もうたべた。

title: Counter expressions
meaning: Words used for counting different types of objects
explanation: Japanese uses special counter words after numbers depending on what is being counted. Common counters include つ (general), 人 (people), 本 (long things), 枚 (flat things), and 台 (machines/vehicles).

exampleSentences.japanese: りんごを三つ買いました。
exampleSentences.reading: りんごをみっつかいました。
がくせいがごにんいます。

title: でしょう - Probably / Right?
explanation: でしょう expresses the speaker's conjecture (probably) or seeks agreement from the listener (right?). With rising intonation, it asks for confirmation.

exampleSentences.reading: あしたはあついでしょう。
exampleSentences.english: It will probably be hot tomorrow.

exampleSentences.japanese: この映画はおもしろいでしょう？
exampleSentences.reading: このえいがはおもしろいでしょう？

title: てもいい - May / It's okay to
meaning: Asks or gives permission to do something
explanation: てもいい is used to ask for or give permission. Adding か makes it a question asking for permission.

exampleSentences.japanese: 写真を撮ってもいいですか。
exampleSentences.reading: しゃしんをとってもいいですか。

exampleSentences.japanese: ここに座ってもいいですよ。
exampleSentences.reading: ここにすわってもいいですよ。

title: てはいけない - Must not
explanation: てはいけません expresses prohibition, meaning that something must not be done.

exampleSentences.japanese: ここで食べてはいけません。
exampleSentences.reading: ここでたべてはいけません。

title: なければならない - Must / Have to
structure: [Verb ない-form without い] なければならない/なりません
explanation: This structure expresses that something must be done. In polite speech, なければなりません is used.

exampleSentences.japanese: 宿題をしなければなりません。
exampleSentences.reading: しゅくだいをしなければなりません。

title: ほうがいい - Had better
structure: [Verb た-form] ほうがいい / [Verb ない-form] ほうがいい
explanation: ほうがいい is used to give advice. With た-form it means 'you should do'. With ない-form it means 'you should not do'.

exampleSentences.japanese: 早く寝たほうがいいですよ。
exampleSentences.reading: はやくねたほうがいいですよ。
exampleSentences.english: You had better go to bed early.

exampleSentences.japanese: 食べないほうがいいです。
exampleSentences.reading: たべないほうがいいです。
exampleSentences.english: You had better not eat it.

title: のが好き / のが上手 - Like doing / Good at doing
meaning: Expresses liking or skill at an activity
structure: [Verb dictionary form] のが 好き/上手/下手
explanation: の nominalizes the verb, turning it into a noun phrase. Combined with が好き, が上手, or が下手, it expresses liking, being good at, or being bad at an activity.

exampleSentences.japanese: 本を読むのが好きです。
exampleSentences.reading: ほんをよむのがすきです。

exampleSentences.japanese: 料理を作るのが上手です。
exampleSentences.reading: りょうりをつくるのがじょうずです。
